documentType: Bureau of Prisons clinical and administrative records
summary: A series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records documenting clinical contacts, suicide risk assessments, and a disciplinary competency evaluation for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 27 to August 1, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY). The records detail his mental status, complaints about conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), an incident involving marks on his neck, and his eventual return to SHU housing. This document contains two Bureau of Prisons mental health clinical intervention reports for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, dated August 1 and August 8, 2019. The reports assess his suicide risk and mental status while housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM). The August 1 report details a prior incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a string around his neck, and concludes his acute suicide risk is low.

events.title: Neck Injury Incident in SHU
events.description: Epstein is found with marks on his neck in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), leading to an incident report for code 228 (Self-Mutilation). He later states he cannot remember how it happened.

events.title: Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein is placed on and remains under daily psychological observation due to the neck injury incident and complaints about SHU conditions, including noise and sleep deprivation.

events.title: Disciplinary Competency Evaluation
events.description: PsyD evaluates Epstein's competency to proceed with the disciplinary process for the July 23 incident report. He is found COMPETENT.

events.title: Court Status Hearing
events.description: Epstein reports going to court for a status hearing on this date.

events.title: US Marshals Form Incident
events.description: Upon return from court, US Marshals present Epstein with a form stating he has 'suicidal tendencies', prompting a new Suicide Risk Assessment on August 1.

events.title: DHO Hearing and Report Expungement
events.description: Epstein reports seeing the Discipline Hearing Officer (DHO) and states his incident report for the neck marks was expunged.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck in SHU
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found by staff in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a string loosely tied around his neck. Epstein stated he did not remember anything about the incident.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A psychology provider (PsyD) conducted a formal suicide risk assessment of Jeffrey Epstein. The assessment noted risk factors (high-profile crime, sex offender status, physical pain) and protective factors (future orientation, supportive lawyers, religious beliefs). The overall acute suicide risk was concluded to be low.

events.title: Follow-up Clinical Session
events.description: The Chief Psychologist conducted a follow-up clinical session with Epstein in the SHU. Epstein reported feeling okay, denied suicidal ideation, and stated he spends his days with his attorneys. No mental health concerns were noted.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY) - Facility NYM
keyFacts: Epstein sustained unexplained marks on his neck while in SHU on July 23, 2019, leading to a self-mutilation incident report. He repeatedly claimed he could not remember how it happened.

Epstein expressed significant distress about returning to SHU, citing extreme noise, an inability to sleep, and a prior incident where a malfunctioning toilet caused him to 'sit in the corner and hold his ears'.
Clinical staff consistently found Epstein competent, not suicidal, and not an immediate danger to himself or others, despite his complaints and the neck injury incident.
On July 31, 2019, after a court hearing, US Marshals asked Epstein to sign a form noting he had 'suicidal tendencies', which surprised him and prompted another suicide risk assessment.
Epstein reported on August 1 that his disciplinary incident report for the neck marks had been expunged following a DHO hearing.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck; he claimed no memory of the event.
A suicide risk assessment on August 1, 2019, concluded Epstein's acute suicide risk was 'Low' and chronic risk was 'Absent,' despite noted risk factors including his high-profile sex offense case.
Epstein reported protective factors against suicide, including future plans to 'finish this case,' supportive visits from his lawyers, and his Jewish religious beliefs against suicide.
During a follow-up on August 8, 2019, Epstein denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan and reported spending his days with his attorneys in the conference room.
The document shows Epstein was housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) and had interactions with a cellmate, though he expressed a desire to be moved to general population.
